title: Utah considers automated approach to deadbeat taxpayers
text:
Utah considers involving banks in collecting delinquent tax payments 
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Published: 10/25/15 3:53 pm EDT - Updated: 10/25/15 3:53 pm EDT 
SALT LAKE CITY â€” Banks and credit unions may soon have to turn over certain customer information to the state. 
The Salt Lake Tribune reports ( http://bit.ly/1OPDvJf ) lawmakers are considering legislation that would make it easier for the state find delinquent taxpayers and garnish their bank accounts. 
The bill calls for an automated database of delinquent taxpayers who have court-issued judgment liens. Banks would be required to search the database and notify the state of any names belonging to account holders. 
Some are worried the system would violate privacy or become vulnerable to access by other creditors. 
State Tax Commission Chairman John Valentine says the current process is expensive and many times does not succeed. 
Committee approval last week puts the bill up for consideration by the full Legislature in January. 
Information from: The Salt Lake Tribune, http://www.sltrib.com
